fields.description:
there should be a way
a) to configure repositories to never incrementally scan
b) request an incremental scan from the commandline
fields.summary: Manually request incremental scan from commandline

fields.description:
We have our SVN mirrored onto our FishEye machine and FishEye setup to scan using a file:/// protocol.

Every once and a while it seems it is unable to get/parse the author and/or the comment (usually it fails to get both) and instead shows the change list in FishEye as having the author of the daemon account that is syncing Subversion with no comment.

If I go onto the box and query the subversion mirror using "svn log" and the same file:/// path, it is able to get the author and comment fine, so it is not a problem with our SVN mirror.

This has occurred about 18 times in the last ~9500 revisions, so it does not occur frequently. Out of those, 3 of the 18 included the comment but still had the daemon account as the incorrect author. The rest were <no comment> with the daemon account listed as the author.

As far as I can tell there is no similarity between the change sets that it misses. They all have different authors, going to different paths and have different comments / comment style.
fields.summary: FishEye occasionally does not get the author and/or comment for change sets

fields.description: In some cases when tagged version was modified or moved from one place to another FishEye will show files inside of it as directories.
fields.summary: Showing files as directories in tags directories

fields.description:
Hello,

There is a bug in that when I am logged in to FishEye/Crucible as a user which is authenticated via Crowd it does not let me access the /admin/ pages. I can put in my password and see the menu, but as soon as I click on a link in the menu it asks me to enter the FishEye admin password again.

I get around this by logging out of the Crowd user. But ideally I would be able to authenticate against the admin console as a user in the fisheye-admin group *(in crowd or any other LDAP dir attached).

Thanks,
Nick
fields.summary: Can't access /admin/ when logged in via Crowd

fields.description:
Attached is a screenshot of a FishEye notification email. Note how the text in the subject line is all mushed together.

Could subject lines either have everything following the first newline stripped, or could they have their newlines replaced by spaces?

(The first suggestion would be my preference.)
fields.summary: Improve email notification handling for commit comments with newlines

fields.description:
Revision tagging is not working for rdiff function in FishEye but we can use the revision number to retrieve the result. 
Tested using a file in fisheye hosting - http://fisheye1.cenqua.com/browse/springframework/spring/src/org/springframework/core/Conventions.java.

For example:

Query (using revision no.) :
* http://fisheye1.cenqua.com/rdiff/springframework/spring/src/org/springframework/core/Conventions.java?r1=1.8&r2=1.7
returns the output.

Query (using revision tag) :
* http://fisheye1.cenqua.com/rdiff/springframework/spring/src/org/springframework/core/Conventions.java?r1=release-2-5-2&r2=release-2-5-1
returns nothing.
fields.summary: CVS rdiff query doesn't work when using tag

fields.description:
From previous correspondance with Conor MacNeill:

>
 > Does not cope well with branch/tag deletions
 >
 > One of the operations which regularly causing blocking of repository
 > scanning is the removal of branches or tags within a Subversion
 > repository.
 > I don't know why this is the case - I opened a query with Cenqua about
 > this - they weren't actually able to tell me the answer as to why it takes
 > so long.

From an external view, a Subversion respository can appear huge. i.e. 
 if you performed an svn listing (ls) on the root of a Subversion 
 repository, which contains 10 branches and 100 tags, the repository will 
 appear to be about 111 times its actual size. This is not a problem for 
 Subversion itself, internally, as its access is predominantly sequential 
 (with respect to the directory hierarchy). As it navigates a path, it 
 can follow copy links - so called cheap copies. As an indexer, FishEye's 
 access to the directory hierarchy is predominantly "random access". 
 Searching with FishEye would be more difficult if it were navigating the 
 directory hierarchy sequentially.

We are actively researching whether we can take advantage of "cheap 
 copy" style linking within FishEye's index to better handle the way 
 Subversion works. In other word, we do recognize the problem and we are 
 working on solutions.

One of the approaches taken within FishEye to mitigate the problem is to 
 recognize tags as such and to tag the original file's entry in the 
 FishEye index. Effectively the tagged directory hierarchy is virtualized 
 by tagging the entries for the source of the tag. This keeps the size of 
 the FishEye index down significantly but does mean that FishEye needs to 
 know when a copy represents a tagging operation.
h3. Workarounds:
 # [Add exclude rules|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/include-exclude-paths-960155516.html#IncludeExcludepaths-AddinganExclude] in order to make Fisheye ignore the paths from the branches and tags that have been deleted.
 # Set a [start revision|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/configuring-repository-details-960155509.html#Configuringrepositorydetails-ConfiguringtheSCMdetailsforarepository] to start indexing from a particular revision.
 # Split a single large repository into logical components (e.g., by project or by product).
 # Change the repository definition so as to look at a subset of your repository by setting [a path|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/configuring-repository-details-960155509.html] within your repository that you wish Fisheye to index.
 # After trying one or more of the suggestions above, saving changes and exiting the repository administration panel a modal window will be presented saying that the repository needs to re-indexed for changes to take effect, and offering two options:
 ** {{*Perform now*}} will immediately erase the repository cache indexed thus far and will start re-indexing the repository from scratch.
 ** {{*Ignore*}} will keep everything indexed thus far, but you need to [stop and start|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/managing-your-repositories-960155450.html] the affected repository to make Fisheye ignore the excluded paths from now onwards.
 # As a general advice, you could benefit from a way faster indexing speed by using file protocol instead of HTTP / HTTPS for connecting to the repository. According to the [Best Practices|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/best-practices-subversion-integration-960155709.html] document, HTTP and HTTPS are the slowest protocols. You can switch to file protocol by either:
 ** [Migrating Fisheye|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/migrating-fisheye-between-servers-960155799.html] to the server where Subversion is installed, or
 ** Using the [svnsync|http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/subversion/trunk/notes/svnsync.txt] utility to mirror the remote repository onto the server where Fisheye is installed.
 # The most important aspect for a large-repository deployment will be disk I/O speed. You definitely want a fast local HDD for Fisheye's cache. Note that NFS and SAN are [not supported|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/supported-platforms-960155252.html]. Perform the [disk access speed test|https://confluence.atlassian.com/kb/test-disk-access-speed-for-jira-server-performance-troubleshooting-818577561.html] and compare your benchmarks with the table shown in the section *Grading the Results* from that document in order to make sure that the HDD speed on the Fisheye server is at least OK for all file operations.
fields.summary: Fisheye copes poorly with branch or tag deletions

Customer is using UTF-8 encoding. For an example see the code comments at: http://svn.seasar2.muleforge.org/browse/seasar2/branches/0.9.2/src/main/java/org/mule/extras/seasar2/sender/impl/S2MuleSenderImpl.java?r1=62&r2=63

The Japanese character in the commit message shown correctly but not in the source code comments.

fields.description:
I have configured a trusted application (JIRA), which works properly until Fisheye needs to be restarted.

At the moment Fisheye is restarted, the configuration file can no longer be parsed, because there seem to be missing document elements:
{code:xml}
INFO  - FishEye 1.4.2 (build-267), Built on 2008-01-14
ERROR - Errors parsing /opt/fisheye/config.xml:
ERROR - in file:/opt/fisheye/config.xml at line 25082: Expected element 'certificateTimeout@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1' before the end of the content in element trustedApplication@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1
Problem with config file: Error parsing config file (see logs): /opt/fisheye/config.xml
{code}

This is a huge blocker, because every time Fisheye is restarted, the trusted application needs to be re-configured.
fields.summary: Trusted Application not stored properly in configuration file

fields.description:
When I navigate to one single file in Crucible, it offers the function "Show Arbitrary Diff". I would like a similar function that can be used on a whole repository or a directory. 

That is, I would like to see a diff (not a changelog) reflecting all the changes that have happened to my project during a certain period of time.

I would like to see the results in one big diff that spans multiple files. It should be similar to the "Changeset Detail" view, except that it would show the accumulated results of multiple changesets. It should have the "Expand all | Collapse all | Truncate Long Diffs" options.
fields.summary: "Show Arbitrary Diff" for repositories and directories

fields.description: reproduced with IE 7.0
fields.summary: Get Id button does not work in Trusted Application screen under IE

fields.description:
When creating a patch review it is not possible to view the full source code of the file.

However, as the diff file contains the path of the file being changed, surely your product could use this path to find the original committed source file, and therefore give me the feature I am looking for ? Is there any technical reason why this could not be implemented, or is it just that you haven't added this feature yet ? If this was done, then the review process would be exactly same as if I had committed the change and then your product created its own diff using latest repository revision, compared with previous revision in repo.

The reason why we don't want to commit changes until they are reviewed is that often an engineer makes some changes and when they are reviewed it turns out that many changes are required, and sometimes a complete re-write. In these case if we committed each change before review it would create a mess in the repository which will make it harder to use when we want to check old revisions.

C/o Tim Alsop
fields.summary: Ability to view full source code when creating a patch review

fields.description:
Our software development is based on Subversion, FishEye and Crucible on Linux platform.
We are a 30 member team of developers.

When the project comes close to QA hand off (or to a major release),
the program managers need to "throttle" the branch. This means:
  1) a special "release" branch is pulled off the mainline
  2) the program manager identifies a set of "must-fix" JIRA defects for the
       release.
  3) Subversion is configured with a pre-commit hook which makes sure that
       only those code commits are permitted which identify a defect from the 
        must-fix defect list in the code commit comment.
   4) As soon as a valid defect is identified, the commit is permitted as usual 
        and the defect is taken off the allowed list.
   5) When the must fix defect list becomes empty, no more commits will be allowed
       by the pre-commit hook.

Would FishEye provide such a capability? If FishEye is a "read only" tool, could you
please point me to such a pre-commit hook for subversion which I can use? This
requirement is not unique to us and I assume some other team must have
invented this capability.

I would immensely appreciate any suggestions/pointers.

Regards,

Rk
(408) 596-1377
fields.summary: Need a subvrsion commit watchdog

fields.description:
The motivation for doing this is that we will be able to inject Crowd dependencies instead of using static factories -- plus it contributes to overall springification.

This is complicated by the fact that we explicitly recreate these objects when configuration changes.

It's kinda frustrating if you just want to review what happened in that change... have to open a new tab/window for each new file.  An additional button that shows new files inline on that page would be great.

Thanks!

fields.description:
Currently you have the option of receiving (watch) emails immediately or as a daily digest. Various improvements are needed:

Basics: 
* Move the timing selection from the "watch" tab of profile to the "email" tab
* Add an hourly digest option

Stretch:
* Allow the user to set the time of day for the daily digest
* Make these digest settings affect Crucible email (CRUC-263)
fields.summary: Email digest improvements

fields.description:
If you have a file of type "unicode" (which is the most proper file type for XML data in modern P4 repositories), they show up as binary, and thus can't be diffed. They should be considered text.

This has nothing to do with whether your p4 server is unicode enabled, which controls the metadata (whether filenames or usernames can be unicode), not the data.
fields.summary: P4 Files of type "unicode" appear as binary

fields.description: It would be nice if there was a way for administrators to view and administer the watch lists.  I would like to be able to pull up who is watching what and also be able to delete certain watches...like right now watches appear to stay configured for users even after they are deleted (FE-280) so it would be useful to be able to go in and delete those watches.
fields.summary: Administer Email Watches

fields.description: Even after a user has been deleted from FishEye, in reviewing some debug log files for Watch Emails, it appears the watches for deleted users still exist and match on changesets.
fields.summary: Still see watch email log messages for deleted users (adds users back too!)

fields.description: The checkboxes on the search screen, 'Search all directories' and 'Only most recent versions', don't use the label tag. That means you can't click them to toggle the checkbox. You need to change the markup from this: {code:html} Search all directories Only most recent versions {code} to this: {code:html} {code}
fields.summary: Use label tag for checkbox labels on Search form

fields.description:
Precondition:
Added Jira as Trusted Application in Fisheye > Admin > Trusted Applications.

Problem:

1. When trying to edit the setting or even delete it, a NullPointerException occurs with the following Message:

{panel}
*FishEye was unable to process your request.*
java.lang.NullPointerException

You are running release FE1.4.3 (build-272 2008-02-07), please report your release number when reporting bugs.

Got a problem or a suggestion? Discuss it in the online forums see the website for other support options. 
{panel}
See attached log file.

2. The links presented in the error message above point to the old Cenqua forums.

3. As you see in the logfile, an IP restriction containing {{ * }} is not possible and rejected with IPAddressFormatException, but should be as stated in the Fisheye 1.4 documentation.

This is the recommended way to run FishEye on a CVS repository where local filesystem access is not possible or practical. In some situations it is also a good idea for Subversion repositories too.  This is how most of fisheye.cenqua.com works.
fields.summary: Document setting up a CVS mirror with rsync

fields.summary: Support protocols such as pserver for remote CVS repositories

fields.description:
For the Apache licensed libraries, we do need to include the Apache license and each individual library's NOTICE file. As per the license.
1. You must give any other recipients of the Work or Derivative Works a copy of this License; and

2. You must cause any modified files to carry prominent notices stating that You changed the files; and

3. You must retain, in the Source form of any Derivative Works that You distribute, all copyright, patent, trademark, and attribution notices from the Source form of the Work, excluding those notices that do not pertain to any part of the Derivative Works; and

4. If the Work includes a "NOTICE" text file as part of its distribution, then any Derivative Works that You distribute must include a readable copy of the attribution notices contained within such NOTICE file, excluding those notices that do not pertain to any part of the Derivative Works, in at least one of the following places: within a NOTICE text file distributed as part of the Derivative Works; within the Source form or documentation, if provided along with the Derivative Works; or, within a display generated by the Derivative Works, if and wherever such third-party notices normally appear. The contents of the NOTICE file are for informational purposes only and do not modify the License. You may add Your own attribution notices within Derivative Works that You distribute, alongside or as an addendum to the NOTICE text from the Work, provided that such additional attribution notices cannot be construed as modifying the License.

I'd say only 1 & 4 apply to use as we are not distributing source.
fields.summary: Include appropriate licence/notice files
When Crowd integration is enabled, Trusted Application requests should use the Crowd Db when determining if users exist

fields.description:
Taken from Matt's comments on the parent issue

slightly related to this issue, it would be perhaps more consistent with the rest of fisheye's URL conventions if logical/physical was a flag in the /~/ "wayback/constraint" section instead of a cookie preference?

That way, when you cut-and-paste a URL to someone, they are guaranteed of seeing what you see (the opposite has occurred to me a few times already).
fields.summary: Make Logical/Physical part of the URL rather than a cookie

fields.description:
It is not clear from documentaion http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/1.6+Subversion what happens when SVN operation times out. Will operation be executed again? Will operation execution enter infinite loop if operation is long and timeout is small?

I see same message "Fetching combined diff for java in revision 595 in https://svn.company.ru/stuff/" for last 4 hours, but the default timeout is 1 hour. What should I do?

Commit 595, however isn't large

svn log -r 595 --verbose

says that about 300 files were added.
fields.summary: What happens when SVN operation times out?

fields.description:

2008-01-31 15:28:04,538 WARN  [SvnTimeout] fisheye.app com.cenqua.fisheye.svn.SvnThrottledClient$1-run - Cancellin
g SVN Operation due to timeout

What operation timed out? Which repository, which revision? Please print this information in log. Maybe I should exclude some directories or revisions from being indexed.

fields.description:

fields.description: It is desirable to be able to expand newly added files when looking at changeset (in addition to expanding diffs).
fields.summary: changeset view: "expand" new file

fields.description:
Refactoring with moving files between packages is a common practice in Java programming. Fisheye quicksearch finds all paths to file, older and newer. However, it is hard to distinguish, which files is actual, and which is old copy.

Look at attached screenshot. GunzipInputStreamSource.java was moved two times, and when looking at quick search page it is impossible to find where the needed file is.

I think unavailable in the last revision files should be marked by strikeout.
fields.summary: quick search should mark deleted files

fields.description:
If I'm looking at a tabular results of a search, it would be extremely useful to be able to aggregate on the different dimensions (user, path, revision) and see aggregated statistics that I can drill into.

Use case here is "show me all changes last year organized by user" and then I can drill down into the branches or paths or revisions to find out more details when I've identified the top 10 code deleters.
fields.summary: Aggregation on search tabular results

fields.description: For example, if I have Total Lines, Lines Added, and Lines Removed, it would be useful to be able to click on the headers to sort by that column.
fields.summary: When doing searching on repositories, sort capabilities on tabular results

fields.description: The little icon in the left margin marking hidden diff context would be a great way to enable the expansion of certain parts of a diff. If I have many changes in a large file, I may want to see all of the context around my changes, but not have to wade through the entire file. It'd be great if I could click on the "lines hidden" indicator and expand just that chunk of context one notch at a time. This would require that a new "lines hidden" indicator be added to the top and bottom of the file.
fields.summary: Allow selective expansion of diff context

fields.description: Every time I restart FishEye for some reason, it goes through an Index Content pass, doing a "p4 print" on every single current file in every repository. This wouldn't be optimal at the worst of times, but with FE-227 and FE-122 it means that a restart with remote depots can take many many hours to become usable.
fields.summary: Don't "Index Content" on every server restart

fields.description:
(5:42 PM) David Soul: i was wondering about fisheye remote api doco
(5:42 PM) David Soul: I am looking at the Fisheye product for use here at Pearson (350
developers & support staff). The following page indicates that Fisheye
offers a "Comprehensive REST API and XML RPC API for integrating FishEye
with existing infrastructure" but I cannot find any documentation
discussing the capabilities offered via the REST API (c.f.
http://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/features/integration.jsp)

I am particularly interested in what access I would have to line count
data retained by Fisheye.
(5:42 PM) David Soul: i cant see any info on the api
(5:46 PM) Ed: This is internal help for the program. There is a HTML page that contains this information which is accessed via context-sensitive help.
(5:47 PM) Ed: To get there, it's Admin screen > Server Settings > then click the green help icon next to "Remote API".

Equity access:
http://equity.sydney.atlassian.com/crucible/api/

Admin screen is documented on this page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/4.+Setting+up+your+Web+Server
fields.summary: Add REST API docs to Confluence

fields.description:
The proxy setup docs for fisheye/crucible at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE013/Integrating+with+Other+Web+Servers are woefully inadequate. 

This is puzzling, since I actually got the proxy working when I found and followed the confluence proxy docs using google: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Using+Apache+with+mod_proxy
fields.summary: Proxy Docs are woefully inadequate

fields.description:
We have a bunch of LDAP users who have duplicate accounts in FishEye that were automatically created. The only difference between them is that one is lower case and the other is mixed case. For example "brian feinstein" and "Brian Feinstein" are both in there, identical except the username case.

Our LDAP security setup looks like this:
URL:	ldap://usmils002.palm1.palmone.com:3268
Base DN:	dc=palm1,dc=palmone,dc=com
User Filter:	(sAMAccountName=${USERNAME})
UID attribute:	sAMAccountName
Email attribute:	mail
Display name attribute:	sAMAccountName
Cache TTL (positive):	5 minutes
Auto-add users into FishEye:	true


This causes two problems right now. First, depending on the case they login with they have two different profiles. Second, they get different treatment by Crucible. For example, a user had crucible access on their lower-cased user name, but not their mixed case user name.

Maybe FishEye needs to do case-insensitive checks in this area? Or give you an option to ignore case for username? I know that JIRA handles this by forcing all usernames to be lowercase.
fields.summary: Duplicate LDAP users created with differing case

fields.description: I think that when I click on the revision number in the margin of an annotation, what I want to see is the change made in that revision, not the annotation at that revision.
fields.summary: Revision link on annotate view should go to diff

fields.description:
Right now, indexing a particular p4 repository appears (from looking at the process tree of a running FishEye instance) to be a serialized sequence of "p4 print" statements. However, "p4 print" is a latency and not bandwidth sensitive operation, and it almost always makes sense to perform these with some degree of parallelism. But it's necessary for FishEye to index a p4d running over a high-latency WAN.

One way to see precisely how bad things can be is to try to index a Perforce repository on a proxy on a WAN (London-->Hong Kong) link, where the proxy isn't hot:

FishEye --> Local p4p --> Remote p4d

If the p4p is cold, it looks like what's happening is that FishEye is running a bunch of "p4 print" operations in series, each of which is quite synchronous and thus latency sensitive (in our case we have more than enough bandwidth to spare). So while you get some minor speedup on a local server at the expense of thrashing your FishEye and P4 installations, you would get MASSIVE performance benefits out of parallelizing the "p4 print" operations to some extent.

This was originally raised as a comment on FE-122 due to a misunderstanding of what that issue really meant.
fields.summary: Internally parallelize p4 print output

fields.description:
It would be particularly useful if you have a complex and changing Perforce permission scheme (done using "p4 protect") that Fisheye would automatically respect that and not force administrators to duplicate the permissioning twice:
- Once in P4 itself
- Once in Fisheye

Particularly this could make things quite complicated under the repository protection scheme, because you'd have to have wholly different repositories to represent the permissions, since permissioning is done against a particular repository and not against a sub-hierarchy.
fields.summary: Pull/synchronize protections from the output of "p4 protect -o"

fields.description:
Potential customers are interested in seeing how FishEye works for large, real-life projects. There is already a great list at http://fisheye.cenqua.com/ that we should import into our new documentation at
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE
fields.summary: List public FishEye instances in FishEye documentation

fields.description:
I have access to two fisheye instances.  They are both configured to accept ajp13 connections, one of them works.  I'm having problems determining why the second one is working other than the versions are different (the configurations are the same).  

To replicate, build a CentOS 5 box, install httpd and configure /etc/httpd/conf.d/proxy_ajp.conf something like:

ProxyPass /fisheye ajp://localhost:8010/fisheye

Clearly, you need to configure fisheye something like:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<config control-bind="127.0.0.1:8059" version="1.0" admin-hash="3BAE00188C94C5DD9CA971F54BB74815" timezone="US/Eastern">
    <!-- see example-config.xml and config.xsd for more documentation -->
    
 <license SID="AXDM-QBD5-PVB4-6T8L"><fisheye>KEY</fisheye><crucible>KEY</crucible></license>
<web-server site-url="http://devcentral.imentorinteractive.org/fisheye/*" context="/fisheye">
        
    <ajp13 bind=":8010"/><http bind=":8060"/></web-server>
    <api enabled="false"/>
    <security allow-anon="false" allow-cru-anon="false">
  <built-in>
   <signup enabled="false"/>
</built-in>
<crowd auto-add="true"><crowd-properties>#Mon Jan 14 19:47:42 EST 2008
application.password=1pw4fisheye
application.name=fisheye
crowd.server.url=http\://localhost\:8095/crowd/services/
</crowd-properties></crowd></security>
    <repository-defaults>
        <linker/>
        <allow/>
        <tarball enabled="false" maxFileCount="0"/>
        <security allow-anon="true"><required-groups/></security>
    <text-indexer enabled="true"/><watches enabled="true"/></repository-defaults>
</config>


Can you see anything obvious that I am missing?  Thanks!
fields.summary: Issue with AJP when connecting from Tomcat from CentOS yum archive

fields.description:
The init method of a custom authenticator is being passed an empty Properties object, despite the fact that custom authentication properties have been set.  

Here is the relevant section of config.xml:

<custom auto-add="true" positive-cache-ttl="5 mins" classname="com.norganna.authenticator.fisheye.VanillaMySQLAuthenticator"><properties># MySQL Setup Variables
AuthMySQLHost=localhost
AuthMySQLUser=<blanked>
AuthMySQLPassword=<blanked>
AuthMySQLDB=<blanked>
AuthMySQLUserTable=LUM_User
AuthMySQLUserNameField=Name
AuthMySQLPassword1=Password
AuthMySQLPassword2=IpbPass
AuthMySQLNameField1=FirstName
AuthMySQLNameField2=LastName
AuthMySQLEmailField=Email</properties></custom>
fields.summary: CLONE -Custom Authenticator's init method is being passed an empty Properties object
